page.title: 10PAST LAND USE: WARLEY, ESSEX
page.content: The 1838 Tithe Map for the parish of Great Warley was consulted in the Essex CRO. The land here is mostly on the{Upper Tertiary.}The following comparisons were noted. 1. In 1838 Great Warley village was much the same size as today. 2. Settlement growth has taken place only in the north, towards Brentwood. 3. The area of woodland has hardly changed. 4. Little has changed in the road network except for the M25 and the introduction of a few farm roads. 5. Most of the land is {now pasture.}In{1838}about{60%}of it was{arable.}This is because Early Victorian farmers found these lighter soils easier to work than the London Clay - which was thus left to pasture - and concentrated on cereal growing, encouraged by the high grain prices offered before the repeal of the Corn Laws.
